name: Using Monk as a minor class: An in-depth guide
author: Orion

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Using Monk as a minor class: An in-depth guide 


Image source: https://steemit.com/dungeonsanddragons/ ... and-d-monk

I had a discussion with Empyre65 recently, who lamented the lack of guides on Monk as a minor class. I've made and played quite a few minor class Monk builds and I was interested in expanding my knowledge on this topic, so I thought it was time to write such a guide up. I'll give it a go! I'm fully aware other builders have played much more Monk than I have so I'm welcoming of feedback from other builders if there is any critique of the content I've created, or if I've missed anything.

Introduction
Monk is a versatile warrior class which as a primary (or major) class is quite powerful defensively and offensively against physical damage, and against spells (particularly with Diamond Soul). As a minor class it provides tremendous benefits as well.

There are a few guides out there which discuss Monk as a primary (or major) class. For example ELaRusic's Monk Guide on GameFAQs (for players new to the class), Alex Trenchard's Monk Guide on GameBanshee (for players new to the class) and Knight_ofLimbo's Monks: An analysis (for advanced players).

This guide will be limited to discussing Monk as a minor class. Such a topic is still sizable to cover and would be aimed at intermediate and advanced players. I haven't identified any guides which particularly focus on this topic so I think I'm adding to what is out there.

For the purpose of this guide I will define minor class as not more than the highest class level in a build. For a pre-epic build (up to character level 20), I would define it as 10 levels or less. For an epic build (up to character level 40) I would define it as 20 levels or less.

The Basics of the Monk Class (for more details read the Monk NWN Wiki Page)
Alignment restriction: Any Lawful
Hit die: d8
Base attack bonus +3/4 levels
Skill points: 4 +Int modifier, (4+int modifier)x 4 at 1st level
Class skills: Concentration, Craft Armor/Trap/Weapon, Discipline, Heal, Hide, Listen, Lore, Move silently, Parry, Persuade, Tumble
Primary saving throws: fortitude, reflex and will
Proficiencies: armor (robes), weapons (monk)
Special: Monk unarmed base attack bonus, allows up to 6 attacks per round, 8 attacks per round with Flurry of Blows and Haste, and 10 attacks per round with dual Kamas, Improved Two Weapon Fighting, Flurry of Blows and Haste. 
Monk weapon proficiencies: club, dagger, handaxe, light crossbow, heavy crossbow, quarterstaff, shuriken, kama, sling

What Monk Provides in a practical sense for builders (summary of the NWN Wiki table for monks)

All Monk levels: access to class skills listed above, d8 hit die, stunning fist once per day per monk level, pre-epic primary saves in Fortitude/Reflex/Will 

Level 1: BAB 0 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+2), Cleave, Monk AC bonus (wisdom), Stunning fist, Evasion, Flurry of blows, Improved unarmed strike, Monk unarmed base attack bonus, weapon proficiency (Monk)
Level 2: BAB 1 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+3), deflect arrows
Level 3: BAB 2 (pre-epic only), monk speed (+10% speed), still mind (+2 to saves against mind affecting spells)
Level 4: BAB 3 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+4), 1d8 unarmed damage (1d6 unarmed damage as a small character)
Level 5: BAB 3 (pre-epic only), purity of body (immunity to non-magical diseases), +1 Monk AC
Level 6: BAB 4 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+5), monk speed (+20% speed), knockdown and improved knockdown
Level 7: BAB 5 (pre epic only), wholeness of body (heal damage equal to twice his/her class level, once per day)
Level 8: BAB 6 (pre epic only), pre-epic save progression (+6), 1d10 unarmed damage (1d8 unarmed as a small character)
Level 9: BAB 6 (pre epic only), improved evasion, monk speed (+30% speed)
Level 10: BAB 7 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+7), ki strike +1, +2 Monk AC
Level 11: BAB 8 (pre-epic only), diamond body (poison immunity)
Level 12: BAB 9 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+8), diamond soul (spell resistance, monk class level +10), 1d12 unarmed damage (1d10 unarmed as a small character), monk speed (+40% speed)
Level 13: BAB 9 (pre-epic only), ki strike +2
Level 14: BAB 10 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+9)
Level 15: BAB 11 (pre-epic only), quivering palm, +3 Monk AC, monk speed (+50% speed)
Level 16: BAB 12 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+10), ki strike +3, 1d20 unarmed damage (2d6 unarmed as a small character)
Level 18: BAB 13 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+11), empty body (50% concealment, twice per day, 1 round/monk level), monk speed (+60% speed)
Level 20: BAB 15 (pre-epic only), pre-epic save progression (+12), perfect self (immunity to mind-affecting spells, damage reduction 20/+1), +4 Monk AC

General comments about taking Monk as a Minor Class
When to take Monk as a minor class
Taking a level of Monk will usually strengthen any build, provided the character meets the lawful alignment requirement. Seven free feats for one level plus a tumble or discipline skill dump is no joke. Plus if that level is taken pre-epic a character can gain +2 to all saves in exchange for 1AB.

If a character meets the lawful alignment requirement (which will usually exclude Bards and Barbarians), the more important question is whether the benefits of taking Monk outweigh the potential benefits of taking a different class which in the end will be a decision for the builder. It might be a different class provides more useful abilities, or provides a better role play element. From a power-gamers perspective, I will outline conditions in which taking Monk is especially favourable, and conditions in which taking Monk is less favourable.

Conditions in which taking Monk is especially favourable
Certain characters will take great advantage of Monk abilities. These include:
- Wisdom based characters such as Clerics and Druids combined with Monk's Wisdom AC, the Stunning Fist and Quivering Palm abilities. For example a character level 40 cleric/monk using robes and no shield with 36 Wisdom (48 when fully capped) will have an extra 13 Wisdom AC (19 AC when wisdom is capped), a Stunning Fist DC of 43-49 and Quivering Palm DC (with sufficient levels of Monk) of 30-36. 
- Polymorph using characters, that use unarmed and unarmored forms to take advantage of Monk Wisdom AC, Monk unarmed attack bonus progression, Monk Speed. This includes Druids, Shifters (unarmed forms), Dragon Shape feat users, casters who make use of the Polymorph self / Shapechange spell. In polymorphed form, the Wisdom attribute remains the same. Therefore polymorphed Druids and Shifters additionally will have powerful Stunning Fist and Quivering Palm abilities as well as high Monk Wisdom AC, if they have high Wisdom scores.
- Sneak attack builds (ie Rogue/Assassin/Blackguard) who take advantage of the multiple attacks provided by the Monk's unarmed base attack bonus progression. Doing up to 8 attacks with flurry and haste or 10 attacks with dual Kamas and improved two weapon fighting, combined with Sneak attack is extremely powerful. A player might be able to do 6d6 sneak attack with 3 attacks per round, for example. If that same character does 6 attacks (from Monk UBAB and flurry), that increases potential sneak attack damage from 18d6 (18 to 108 damage) to 36d6 (36 to 216 damage).
- Bonus damage per attack builds making use of the multiple attacks provided by the Monk's unarmed base attack bonus progression. Doing up to 8 attacks with flurry and haste or 10 attacks with dual Kamas and improved two weapon fighting, combined with +damage per attack is extremely powerful. This includes Fighters with Weapon Specialisation/Epic Weapon Specialisation, Rangers (with favoured enemies and two weapon fighting/ambidexterity/improved two weapon fighting feats for free in robes), Paladins and Blackguards using the Divine Might ability, Paladin / Clerics (using Divine Favor, Darkfire, Greater Magic Weapon and Divine Might) and Red Dragon Disciples (+8 Str).
- Critical hit builds combined with the the Monk's unarmed base attack bonus progression. With the large number of attacks a Monk does, combined with a wide and enhanced critical hit ability (including Devastating Critical), means critical hits will occur more often due to the higher number of hits / round.
- Builds that wish to obtain Improved Knockdown without requiring INT 13. This includes sneak attack type builds and polymorph builds. 
- Ranged weapon users / ranged spell casters making use of Monk Speed. This allows such classes to stay away from enemies with increased movement speed. Such classes include Arcane Archers, Wizards and Sorcerers. 
- Characters with high reflex saves that do not usually take the Evasion feat (such as Paladins, Blackguards, Champion of Torms, Paladin/Sorcerer builds, Blackguard/Sorcerer builds)
- Characters that want access to unbreachable spell resistance (from the Diamond Soul feat)

Screenshot of my Druid 8/Monk 1 character Simond Wetter, fighting a Great Wyvern in Bear Form in the Goblin Territories of the Pomarj on the World of Greyhawk Persistent World server. I'm buffed with Bull's Strength, Barkskin, Stoneskin and other spells. I have a tumble score of 10 from my Monk level for an extra 2 AC. In Bear form, my strength would be between 32-38. When polymorphed into a bear, I retain my Monk Unarmed Base Attack Bonus (essentially doubling the number of my attacks), Monk Wisdom AC and have access to Flurry of Blows and Stunning Fist. As a primary Druid, my Wisdom Score  is 20 plus buffs which when added to the Tumble 10 skill obtained through Monk, translates to an additional 7+ AC to my Bear form from my Monk Level.

More details on how Monk enhances speed casters
I have had to spend a bit of time to understand this concept, and I will try my best to explain. This is from the NWN Wiki on Movement Rate:
The maximum modified movement rate is 150% of base speed, with an exception for monks (level 3 or higher) who can travel at (300 + monk speed)% of base speed (this is 430% of base speed for a level 40 monk). 
[...]
The base movement speed of a running player character is 4 meters per second (mps). 
[...]
Movement rates are not affected by polymorphing.
And this is from the spell NWN Wiki on Expeditious retreat
[...] This spell has no effect if the caster is already hasted.

Notes 
  • Added in the expansion packs.
  • This spell gives a 50% bonus to movement speed not a 150%.
  • The "if the caster is already hasted" clause refers specifically to the spell haste; other sources of haste (including mass haste) do not block this spell (but the movement rate cap is often relevant).
  • This spell stacks with itself (up to the movement rate cap).
The key elements here to understand speed casters are the following:
- The Monk Speed feat increases the maximum modified movement rate from 150% of base speed to 310% of base speed at Level 3, and is additive.
- The Expeditious Retreat spell movement bonus can stack on itself and is multiplicative.
- The standard 'Haste' spell movement speed bonus will not stack with the movement speed increase from Expeditious Retreat.
- Other sources of Haste (such as 'Mass Haste' and Haste from Boots of Speed) will stack with Expeditious Retreat and is multiplicative.

So if a speed caster, with 3 levels of monk, casts the spells Expeditious Retreat twice on him/herself, or Expeditious Retreat and Mass Haste, they will be able to move very close to the movement speed cap. I have verified this in game. I have also verified that the perma-haste from Boots of Speed also stacks with Expeditious Retreat, but will not stack with the spell 'Mass Haste'. 

WhiZard in his post on the Speed Caster: Sorcerer 36/Monk 3/Paladin 1, outlined the maths behind Speed Casting in more details, and the benefits of playing a Speed Caster build. This is from his post: 
WhiZard:
Speed Caster (Sorc 36/Monk 3/Pal 1)
This build features an added benefit to the exalted sorceress template- that is, fast speed.  The normal 1.5 * base speed cap to movement speed is overridden by monk speed (at monk 3) and stacking of speed bonuses occur as follows: Initial Speed = 1.00(base speed) + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.10.  Cast Mass Haste for 1.5 * Initial Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.1 + 0.1 = 1.75.  Cast expeditious retreat for 1.5 * Mass Haste Speed + 0.1(monk bonus) = 1.5 * 1.75 + 0.1 = 2.725. That speed can outrun any natural monk (monk 39 moves at 2.30), giving the sorcerer a huge edge in casting and running without getting caught.  If both spells are extended you can have 7 full turns at this fantastic speed, which is probably enough time to allow you to unleash your spell arsenal.
What does fast speed give?  
Improved herding skills.  See that mob of scattered melee enemies all moving the same speed? Simply circle around the mob again and again and watch it cluster together.  When it becomes a compact group unleash your area of effect spells.  (Oh, and since your hasted you cast in half the usual time, so while herding you can still cast spells without being attacked).
Run past your enemies to the advantageous terrain.  See that cliff? The way up is far away but you can make it there and run back on top of the cliff, leaving your enemies unable to determine which way to go to reach you.
Avoid the bosses.   Those nasty monsters that can dish out hundreds of damage with their smite (or whatever power) seem a lot less threatening if they cannot attack before collapsing.

[...]

WhiZard (reply to HipMaestro):
Here's the full description, the formative parts of which can be found in the talk page of the monk article at the NWN wiki.

Monk speed is an additive bonus reflecting a percentage of the base speed (normal speed with or without encumbrance, stealth/detect mode, running/walking).
Speed increases and decreases (as can be found with haste, slow, and expeditious retreat) are multiplicative bonuses that base their increase/decrease on the current speed.
--
When a speed increase/decrease is added a recursive formulation follows multiplying first and then re-adding the monk bonus.
When a speed increase/decrease is removed then the speed is recalculated multiplying first and then adding the monk bonus once thereafter.
--
The spells haste, expeditious retreat, and blinding speed try to be mutual exclusive, thus their scripts do not allow for stacking.
--
The cap for one with monk speed is (3.0 + monk speed bonus) * base speed.  Without monk speed the cap is 1.5 * base speed.

--
--
Thus for direct answers.  

Perma-haste does stack with expeditious (though without monk speed either of the two already reaches the cap).  Just remember to unequip and reequip the perma-haste item whenever you lose a speed affecting effect (this causes the monk speed to be considered multiple times).

A monk 6 build with mass haste and expeditious retreat has pretty much reached full potential ((1.2 * 1.5) + 0.2) * 1.5 + 0.2) = 3.2 which is the cap (3.0 + 0.2) for a level 6 monk.  After that every three monk levels only increases the speed by 0.1 because of the cap.  Though every 3 levels of monk means 6 less rounds of extended expeditious retreat and extended mass haste.
Further reading: NWN Wiki, Talk:Monk/Archive 1

Conditions in which taking Monk is less favourable
- non-lawful characters (ie Bards, Barbarians) which would require alignment change to be legal
- characters using armor and/or shield. These characters will find the Monk UBAB/Wisdom AC/Monk AC and Monk speed abilities are disabled. The character still gets the other benefits of the Monk class however (including Evasion, Deflect Arrows, +2 to saves against mind affecting spells, Improved Knockdown, Improved Evasion, Diamond Soul etc...)
- non-Wisdom focused characters using robes but weapons other than unarmed/Kamas. Such characters will find the Monk UBAB is disabled but all the other benefits of the Monk class are accessible.
- arcane spellcasters with low Wisdom scores and low reflex saves, who cannot take advantage of Monk UBAB, Monk Wisdom AC and Evasion. Such characters, providing they are wearing robes, will still benefit from Monk Speed and other benefits of the Monk class. Note that negative Wisdom modifiers do not reduce a characters AC (https://nwn.fandom.com/wiki/Monk_AC_bonus). 
- dexterity based characters without access to Uncanny Dodge (Uncanny Dodge will preserve the Dexterity Bonus to AC, even if flatfooted, and the Monk Class does not provide this)
- if there are already three classes in a build, and the builder does not want to lose one of those classes

How many levels to take in Monk as a minor class
A single level of Monk
One level of Monk provides enormous value. 

It provides +2 to all saves at the expense of 1 BAB (if taken pre-epic), 7 feats, access to the Monk unarmed base attack bonus (ie up to 6 attacks per round unarmed or with a single Kama, or up to 8 attacks per round with dual Kamas and improved two weapon fighting) and the ability to access the class skills listed above for 'skill dumps' (particularly Tumble, Hide/Move Silently, Listen, Persuade and Discipline). 

The benefits from this single level of Monk depends on the playstyle of the character:
- if using robes and unarmed/Kamas, then full benefits are obtained
- if using robes but other weapons, the Monk unarmed base attack bonus is disabled. Other benefits of the class remain.
- if using armor and/or a shield, the Monk unarmed base attack bonus, Monk Wisdom AC bonus are disabled. Other benefits of the class remain.

More than a single level of Monk
Extra levels of Monk are also useful depending on what the build requires and how many levels the primary class requires. For example a Paladin build might not want more than 24 levels as this grants access to being undispellable apart from Mord's, and extra levels in other classes may be more beneficial than advancing Paladin further. 

Further sweet spots to stop taking Monk in designing builds are (and these are not 'hard and fast' rules): 
- 3 monk levels (for deflect arrows, +10% speed and +2 to saves against mind affecting spells), 
- 6 monk levels (for +1 Monk AC, +20% speed, knockdown and improved knockdown), 
- 9 monk levels (for +30% Monk speed and improved evasion) 
- 12 monk levels (for diamond soul, +40% monk speed and 1d12 unarmed damage)
- 15 monk levels (for quivering palm, +3 Monk AC, +50% Monk speed)
- 16 monk levels (for ki strike +3, 1d20 unarmed damage)
- 18 monk levels (for empty body, Monk speed +60%) 
- 20 monk levels (for perfect self, +4 Monk AC) - such characters are essentially primary Monks however

I mention these are not 'hard and fast', as Monk provides access to Tumble, Listen and Discipline as class skills. This means further levels can be used for skill dumps. 

For example, a character may want to take Monk 6 to access Improved Knockdown in a build that otherwise would not have access to Tumble as a class skill. For playability the 6th level of Monk might be taken mid way through the build. A further 1-2 Monk levels say at level 27/32 and/or 37 would allow further skill dumps into Tumble to get extra AC. 

The benefits from these Monk levels depends on the playstyle of the character:
- if using robes and unarmed/Kamas, then full benefits are obtained
- if using robes but other weapons, the Monk unarmed base attack bonus is disabled. Other benefits of the class remain.
- if using armor and/or a shield, the Monk unarmed base attack bonus, Monk Wisdom AC bonus, additional Monk AC bonus and Monk Speed bonuses are disabled. Other benefits of the class remain.

Edits: Removed comment on 'Sweet spot' for single level of Monk. Provided example why additional Monk levels above the sweet spots listed would be valuable for skill dumps. Added links to a few more primary monk guides. Fixed a typo in the BAB progression part of Monk. Added a section on the mechanics of Speed Casters. Added KailPendragon's Order of Jormundgandr build to the list of minor class monk builds, commented on how it is no longer legal due to the patch changing Dragon Shape pre-requisites, and how it could be worked around.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Another worthy addition to the Guild's canon, thanks, Orion!

I would have thrown a big fat "like" your way except for my personal antipathy for "Monk-cheese". I do, of course, appreciate its value - and you explain it very well - but it just gets under my skin for some reason: can't help it.

And I'd push for a full-blown Monk Guide (yes, Empyre, I'd be looking at you ), but it's just so damned versatile a class it could go on for ever. It's probably only just behind Bard and Rogue in its usefulness.

Oh sod it, have the "like".

Go well - cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Nice mini-guide so far Orion.

You should also clarify a bit about the speed multiplication that "speed-casters" use and I believe that you have a minor mistake in your BAB table, (it should end at 15), unless it's me talking without coffee.

Monk AC bonus also becomes increasingly irrelevant the higher the magic-level of the module becomes, because it can't keep up with shield enchantments, etc.

There is also another dragon-build with minor Monk levels, it's not listed anywhere because none of us yet posted (but we should do) an updated "Order of jormungandr", perhaps a class-split of (Druid 18/ Monk 2/ Cleric 20) would be best for both power & playability.

Regardless, I like your Initiative & your structured post, keep going!

Thanks everyone for your supportive feedback!

I've added a section on the mechanics of speed-casters and put in some quotes from WhiZard from his Speed Caster build regarding how the mechanics works. I've also tested it in game. Thank you so much for pointing this out. I learnt a lot about speed casting mechanics going through it. Its actually a lot simpler than I thought it would be.

I've fixed the typo in the BAB table. 

I've added a link to the Order of Jorumndgandr written by KailPendragon. I didn't initially include it because of the patch changing pre-requisites to Dragon Shape but I can see it was a hugely popular build and it deserves mentioning. 

Thanks for your comments on making the build playable with NWN v1.69. I agree with your class split to recommend two levels of Monk. Taking an early Monk level (rather than at 37) allows the character to play more of the game with polymorph forms with Monk abilities, rather than having to wait until level 39 (which is what Kail wrote).
